answers.body_markdown:
[(2) is basically implemented][1] as (1), and both may emit 50,000 inserts during flush, if the ORM has to fetch generated values such as primary keys. They may even emit more, if those 50,000 objects have relationships that cascade.

```
In [4]: session.add_all([Foo() for _ in range(5)])

In [5]: session.commit()
BEGIN (implicit)
INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES RETURNING foo.id
{}
... (repeats 3 times)
INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES RETURNING foo.id
{}
COMMIT
```

If you provide primary keys and other DB generated values beforehand, then the `Session` can combine separate inserts to a single "executemany" operation when the arguments match.

```
In [8]: session.add_all([Foo(id=i) for i in range(5)])

In [9]: session.commit()
BEGIN (implicit)
INSERT INTO foo (id) VALUES (%(id)s)
({'id': 0}, {'id': 1}, {'id': 2}, {'id': 3}, {'id': 4})
COMMIT
```

If your DB-API driver implements [`executemany()`][2] or [equivalent][4] using a method that allows it to issue a single statement with multiple data, then it can result in a single query. For example after enabling [`executemany_mode='values'`][3] the Postgresql log contains for the above

```
LOG: statement: INSERT INTO foo (id) VALUES (0),(1),(2),(3),(4)
```

The bulk operation skips most of the `Session` machinery — such as persisting related objects — in exchange for performance gains. For example by default it does not fetch default values, such as primary keys, which allows it to try and batch changes to fewer "executemany" operations where the operation and arguments match.

```
In [12]: session.bulk_save_objects([Foo() for _ in range(5)])
BEGIN (implicit)
INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES
({}, {}, {}, {}, {})

In [13]: session.commit()
COMMIT
```

It may still emit multiple statements, again depending on the data, and the DB-API driver in use. The [documentation][5] is a good read.

With [psycopg2 fast execution helpers][4] enabled the above produces in the Postgresql log

```
LOG: statement: INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES;INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES;INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES;INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES;INSERT INTO foo DEFAULT VALUES
```

In other words multiple statements have been joined to a "single" statement sent to the server.


So, in the end the answer to all 3 is "it depends", which of course may seem frustrating.


  [1]: https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/blob/master/lib/sqlalchemy/orm/session.py#L1996
  [2]: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/#executemany
  [3]: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/dialects/postgresql.html#psycopg2-executemany-mode
  [4]: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/dialects/postgresql.html#psycopg2-fast-execution-helpers
  [5]: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/session_api.html#sqlalchemy.orm.session.Session.bulk_save_objects

answers.body_markdown:
As far as I know there is no such thing as an automatic function to support different screen sizes. 

What you can do: 

 1. Use constraintLayout 
 2. Use `match_parent` and `wrap_content` instead of hard-coded sizes in your xml
 3. Create different layouts for almost every (if not every) screen resolution: 
    ldpi, mdpi, hdpi, xhdpi, xxhdpi
 4. Use stretchable nine-patch bitmaps for image resources.
 5. Consider using fragments and double-pane structure for large devices
 
You may want to chek this library: [https://github.com/intuit/sdp][1]

and this one for text size: [https://github.com/intuit/ssp][2]

Don't forget to test it in as many devices with different resolutions and pixel density as you can.

You can check the official documentation for this issue: [Android developers: Support different screen sizes][3]


  [1]: https://github.com/intuit/sdp
  [2]: https://github.com/intuit/ssp
  [3]: https://developer.android.com/training/multiscreen/screensizes

answers.title: How to set 1000 threads which needs to completed in 1 minute(60 sec) by using stepping thread group in jmeter?

answers.body_markdown:
1000 threads (virtual users) will produce 1000 requests in one minute only under specific condition: **response time must be 16.6 milliseconds**. 

- If response time will be higher - JMeter will execute less requests
- If response time will be lower - JMeter will execute more requests

If you want JMeter to conduct the load at rate of 1000 requests per minute it's better to consider [Concurrency Thread Group][1] and [Throughput Shaping Timer][2] combination

Throughput Shaping Timer configuration:

[![enter image description here][3]][3]

Concurrency Thread Group configuration:

[![enter image description here][4]][4]


  [1]: https://jmeter-plugins.org/wiki/ConcurrencyThreadGroup/
  [2]: https://www.blazemeter.com/blog/using-jmeters-throughput-shaping-timer-plugin/
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/UkpRZ.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/wYueG.png

items.body_markdown:
I am building an application which has a front-end (a SPA built with Vue.js) which interfaces to a couple json-based Web APIs in the back end (hosted in Azure). The Web APIs need to be secured via Azure Active Directory and users must be a member of a security group. Furthermore, the SPA should simply try to force the user to sign into an approved account if they are not signed in as one (i.e. just auto-redirect).

I actually have all this working. The AAD application has Group.Read.All, the user signs in via the SPA and gives consent, and the SPA calls getMemberGroups. Furthermore, the Web APIs can check the SPA-provided access token, and the Web APIs unfortunately must also call getMemberGroups.

And I think that is my concern. The Web APIs keep having to call getMemberGroups to lock it down. If I did the auth on the service, I could potentially only return an access token once membership groups has been verified. But then I lose the easy MSAL sign-in model in the SPA - the Web APIs don't actually provide any front end, the SPA is statically hosted.

As far as I can tell, I cannot get Azure Active Directory to create a token guaranteed to have certain group claims in it. I think this would solve my problem.

Can somebody offer some advice on the best way to design an auth model around a SPA + Web API environment? Or is the method I have taken the only way to do it?

Thanks!
items.title: Checking Azure Active Directory group membership via MSAL in a SPA + Web APIs

answers.title: Is it Possible to Reply From an .EML file?

answers.body_markdown:
Step 1:-
Click the message options menu in the top right corner of the message. Select Save email.

Step 2:-
Save the file. The file name will default to the subject line of the email, with special characters removed. Your download options depend on whether you're using Front on the web or in the desktop app:

*Web: Your file automatically saves to wherever you have it set up in your browser settings (like your Downloads folder)

*Desktop app: You will get the “Save As” prompt where you can rename the file and choose your download location

Step 3:-
You will see your .eml file in your chosen location. You can attach it to a message via drag-and-drop or with the attachment file picker.
answers.title: Is it Possible to Reply From an .EML file?

answers.body_markdown: No you can't do this using the EWS reply operations because EWS is a Server side API while using the EWS Managed API you using Client side library that just instrumenting the SOAP call to the backend whenever an action is taken.  You can temporary import the EML back in the server https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/exchange-web-services/how-to-import-items-by-using-ews-in-exchange and then you reply and then delete the Message again if don't want it to exist. If your want to send using EWS you didn't want to import the message use something like mimekit to generate the MIME of the response message offline http://www.mimekit.net/docs/html/Frequently-Asked-Questions.htm then you can just sent the Mime generated by mimekit via EWS.

answers.body_markdown:
You haven't specified, but the below answer extrapolates your statements regarding how you've "[minimized] or [closed]" your "remote computer" to assume you're leveraging Microsoft's Remote Desktop Connection utility/protocol.

Blue Prism specifically discourages the use of Remote Desktop to manipulate remote Runtime Resources within a Blue Prism-based environment, as the use of the protocol itself causes the methodologies Blue Prism uses to locate elements in the Windows desktop environment to stop working entirely. This is explicitly spelled out in [Blue Prism's official documentation on Remote Access Tools](https://portal.blueprism.com/system/files/2017-11/v6%20Data%20Sheet%20-%20Remote%20Access%20Tools.pdf):

> The following tools have been deemed to be **specifically unsuitable** for
> providing remote access to Blue Prism environments:
> 
> - **Remote Desktop Connection (RDP)**<br />
>   The way that this Windows tool (and other tools that
> use the RDP protocol) handle session management is not compatible with
> Blue Prism:
>
 >  - The underlying operating system is aware as a connection is established which can, subject to the automation techniques being
> applied, result in the executing automation being interupted.
>  - It requires the remote access credentials to be aligned with the credentials used to authenticate the target system against the network
> which presents a potential security risk.
>  - As a user authenticates any previously connected users are locked out.
>  - Each connection creates a separate desktop session.
>  - The connection is not maintained throughout a system reboot.
answers.title: Why does my virtual machine stop conducting blueprism automated processes when I minimize or close it?

answers.body_markdown:
Any file with a front-matter will be processed by jekyll...

eg : **anyfile-with-front-matter.js**

    ---
    title: my js file
    ---
    console.log({{page.title}});
    console.log({{site.description}});

..., except if it is "**ignored**".

By default :

  - any underscored folder is ignored (eg: _myfolder)
  - node_modules, vendor/bundle/, vendor/cache/, vendor/gems/ and vendor/ruby/ folders are ignored by default configuration

To make contained files available to process, you can add containing folders to include array in your **_config.yml**.

    include:
     - node_modules
     - _myfolder

That's my guess.

answers.title: Select procedure in oracle against any column

answers.body_markdown:
Don't use dynamic SQL or, if you must use dynamic SQL then either whitelist the column names or perform some sort of validation of the column name to make sure it is a valid SQL identifier.

Without dynamic SQL:

```sql
CREATE PROCEDURE test (
  in_column_name IN  VARCHAR2,
  in_value       IN  VARCHAR2,
  out_cursor     OUT SYS_REFCURSOR
)
IS
BEGIN
  OPEN out_cursor FOR
    SELECT *
    FROM   employees
    WHERE  CASE UPPER( in_column_name )
           WHEN 'FIRST_NAME' THEN first_name
           WHEN 'LAST_NAME'  THEN last_name
           WHEN 'SALARY'     THEN TO_CHAR( salary )
           WHEN 'DEPARTMENT' THEN department
           ELSE                   NULL
           END
           = in_value;
END;
/
```

With dynamic SQL - whitelist the columns and use a bind variable for the value:

```sql
CREATE PROCEDURE test2 (
  in_column_name IN  VARCHAR2,
  in_value       IN  VARCHAR2,
  out_cursor     OUT SYS_REFCURSOR
)
IS
BEGIN
  IF UPPER( in_column_name ) NOT IN ( 'FIRST_NAME', 'LAST_NAME', 'DEPARTMENT', 'SALARY' )
  THEN
    raise_application_error( -20000, 'Invalid Column Name' );
  END IF;
  OPEN out_cursor FOR
    'SELECT * FROM employees WHERE ' || in_column_name || ' = :value'
    USING in_value;
END;
/
```

With Dynamic SQL - use `DBMS_ASSERT` to validate the column name and a bind variable for the value:

```sql
CREATE PROCEDURE test3 (
  in_column_name IN  VARCHAR2,
  in_value       IN  VARCHAR2,
  out_cursor     OUT SYS_REFCURSOR
)
IS
BEGIN
  OPEN out_cursor FOR
    'SELECT * FROM employees WHERE ' || DBMS_ASSERT.SIMPLE_SQL_NAME( in_column_name ) || ' = :value'
    USING in_value;
END;
/
```

[db<>fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=oracle_11.2&fiddle=ac5cfeadadf1c56a024d1ddfec6a6567)

All attributes in C# have to reference a type defining that attribute *somewhere*. That Blazor code is still C#.

In general, if you have the code in front of you (generally a good idea when watching a tutorial, if at all possible) you can hover over the attribute in Visual Studio to see its fully qualified name or navigate to it.

answers.body_markdown:
You just compile the model two different times, specifying each time a different loss:

    # 30% samples use categorical_crossentropy loss
    model.compile(optimizer, loss='categorical_crossentropy')
    model.fit(X30, y30)
    
    # [...] do stuff if needed

    # 70% samples use mse loss
    model.compile(optimizer, loss='mse')
    model.fit(X70, y70)   

Notice that compiling the model does not affect its weights.
answers.title: How to implement different samples use different losses

`weka.core` is not a Python module, as the error states.

If you are trying to import the `jvm` module (eg for starting/stopping the JVM), then do something like `import weka.core.jvm as jvm`.
